source.raw_text:
The Neutral-Grip Hang Knees-Up targets your abs (rectus abdominis, obliques), hip flexors, and builds grip/forearm strength, with your lats, shoulders, and serratus anterior stabilizing isometrically; the movement pattern involves controlled hip and spinal flexion (pulling knees up) while resisting momentum and arching the back, promoting full-body stability and core power through a functional, full-range motion. [1, 2, 3]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Core): 

    • Rectus Abdominis: The "six-pack" muscle, responsible for spinal flexion (bringing torso towards legs). 
    • Obliques (Internal & External): Stabilize the torso and resist rotation, crucial for core stability. 
    • Hip Flexors (Iliopsoas): Lift the knees toward the chest. 

• Stabilizers & Support: 

    • Forearms & Hands: Maintain grip on the bar. 
    • Latissimus Dorsi (Lats): Engage to keep the body stable and prevent swinging. 
    • Serratus Anterior: Assists in shoulder girdle stability. 
    • Glutes & Lower Back: Engage to prevent arching and maintain a hollow body. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  

Movement Pattern & Technique 

1. Starting Position (Active Hang): Hang from the bar with palms facing each other (neutral grip), shoulders engaged (not slumped), and feet off the floor, creating a stable "hollow body" position. 
2. Concentric (Upward) Phase: Exhale as you initiate the movement by flexing your hips and spine, driving your knees up towards your chest, aiming for 90 degrees at the hips. 
3. Peak Contraction: Squeeze your abs at the top; the higher you lift, the more lower abdominal/pelvic rotation engages the abs. 
4. Eccentric (Downward) Phase: Inhale as you slowly and with control lower your legs back to the starting position, resisting gravity to prevent swinging. 
5. Key Technique: Focus on pulling with your abs, not just your hip flexors, and avoid arching your lower back or using momentum. [1, 2, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]  

**Citations:**

[1] https://www.healthline.com/health/fitness/hanging-knee-raises
[2] https://www.muscleandfitness.com/workouts/abs-and-core-exercises/how-to-hanging-knee-raises-muscles-trained-benefits-mistakes-and-fixes/
[3] https://www.masterclass.com/articles/hanging-knee-raises-guide
[4] https://www.verywellfit.com/how-to-do-the-captains-chair-hanging-leg-raise-3498291
